actions.headline: Get in touch sooner than later
actions.text: Taking the initiative to contact your landlord will help build trust. Try giving him/her a call and saying something like, “Hi (landlord), just wanted to make you aware that I’m having some trouble with the rent this month. I’m very sorry for the inconvenience, and I hope we can work out a plan to get it paid as soon as possible.” This allows your landlord to consider their options as well as yours in a calm, and informed way.

actions.headline: Be easy to reach
actions.text: Be sure to answer any calls, emails or texts from your landlord as soon as you receive them. When you are responsive, you show your landlord that you respect his/her time and that you aren’t going to disappear.

actions.headline: Suggest solutions
actions.text: You want your landlord to know that you eventually intend to pay. As a show of good faith, it’s very helpful to suggest temporary or alternate solutions, such as a partial payment or a payment plan.

actions.headline: Apologies are better than excuses
actions.text: Unless the details of your situation will lead to a viable payment solution, then it’s best not to offer any extra information. Simply apologize and focus on the best way to get your rent paid in the shortest amount of time.

actions.headline: Call your utility provider
actions.text: Your utility company may have a program that can help people pay their bills, including creating a payment plan.

actions.headline: Find government assistance
actions.text: Many state and local government agencies have programs that can help with your utility bill. Find out more here:

actions.headline: Apply for LIHEAP
actions.text: Assistance is available through the federal Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. Each state is different, so make sure to look up your state and ask about what it takes to qualify.

criteria: Residents with very young children, elderly, or disabled family members.
Homes with low-incomes and high regional costs.

actions.headline: Contact your local 2-1-1
actions.text: They can connect you with other organizations that help with housing issues. See what’s available near you.

actions.headline: Find a Catholic Charities agency
actions.text: They help people with housing issues all the time. See what’s available in your neighborhood.

actions.headline: Apply for a Modest Needs grant
actions.text: These small, emergency sums of money are allocated to low-income workers. Find out more by visiting their website.

actions.headline: Talk to a counselor
actions.text: If you won’t be able to pay your rent for a while, then a free session with a housing counselor is the best option for you. They can give you personalized advice and are qualified to understand the special details of your situation.

link.text: FIND A HOUSING COUNSELOR NEAR YOU

actions.headline: Open a savings account
actions.text: When you save small amounts of money over time, you create a safety net for any unexpected bills. Have a savings goal in mind when you open your account, and it will give you the motivation to get started.

actions.headline: Start with a dollar today
actions.text: One dollar is all it takes to start saving. If you start small, and as soon as possible, you’ll set yourself up for future success.

actions.headline: Set up an automatic withdrawal
actions.text: Automatic withdrawal helps you save without having to think about it. Every month, some money from your checking account can be automatically deposited into your savings account. Decide on an amount that works for you, and ask your bank about it. Even $10 a month can make a big difference.

actions.headline: Find a savings buddy
actions.text: Find a friend that is also learning how to save and you can help each other stay on track. Whenever you’re feeling tempted or if saving feels difficult, this person will help you stay motivated.

actions.headline: Save all documents and seek help
actions.text: Save all documents and seek help immediately from a Legal Aid attorney. These are attorneys provided by the court for those of us who can’t afford a lawyer and they can help you understand the eviction process, your rights, and your options. Your new attorney will need to see all notices, letters, or emails from your landlord, as well as from any other lawyers or courts.

link.text: FIND LEGAL HELP NEAR YOU NOW

actions.headline: Apply for unemployment benefits
actions.text: Don’t wait to file! After you fill out your application, it can take a few weeks to get your first check.

8.text: See if you qualify for any government benefits

actions.headline: Take the Benefits assessment
actions.text: Government benefits can help with anything from food bills to doctors bills. Even if you don’t qualify for help with your rent bill, you might qualify for something else that will free up more money for your rent.

actions.headline: Save all documents and seek help
actions.text: Save all documents and seek help immediately from a Legal Aid attorney. These are attorneys provided by the court for those who can’t afford a lawyer and they can help you understand the eviction process, your rights, and your options. Your new attorney will need to see all notices, letters, or emails from your landlord as well as from any other lawyers or courts.

link.text: FIND LEGAL HELP NEAR YOU NOW

actions.text: If you won't be able to pay your rent for a while, the best thing you can do right now is get personalized advice from a counselor.

link.text: FIND A HOUSING COUNSELOR NEAR YOU
